introduction.p: After completing this lesson you will be able to:

li.p: Interpret the meaning of function notation.
Use function notation to describe an event.
Evaluate a function and solve an equation using function notation.

introduction.p: In this activity we define a function and develop an understanding of function notation by comparing statements we already understand in English to equivalent statements written in math language.
The prerequisites for this lesson are knowing how to read a graph or a table of values and how to use a formula to make a calculation.

subsection.title: What is a Function?
subsection.p: According to Wikipedia, a function has the following definition:

p.q: In mathematics, a function is a relation between a set of inputs and a set of permissible outputs with the property that each input is related to exactly one output.

subsection.p: If you actually read the entire Wikipedia entry you will find the definition of a function can be quite lengthy in order to cover all the universe of mathematics. In this activity we are going to keep the language simple, informal and we will use some analogies and examples to arrive at a working definition of functions.
Start by remebmering this: one input, one output.

A functionfunction is a rule that takes a piece of usable information that you pick (input) and gives you some kind of result (output). By usable we mean information that has meaning for the function.

A simple example is that of the outside temperature throughout the day in your neighborhood. You pick a time to walk outside, like 10 a.m. That is an input. The result of making that choice may be an outside temperature of 42 degress fahrenheit. That is an output.

But no matter what time you pick to go outside, there is only one temperature. It's not like it can be 42 degrees and 75 degrees at the same time. Also, using 24 hour time, you can choose to go outside at 10 hours or 15 hours. But you can't go outside at 37 hours because it makes no sense. There are only 24 hours in a day. The input of 37 hours is not usable.

Before we go further in defining a function, we need a short to write and talk about functions. We need some notation so we don't have to keep writing all those letters, F U N C T I O N, that's just way too many letters.

subsection.title: Math as a Language
subsection.p: Math is just another language and everything you say or describe in English, you can say or describe in Math. Math is a language specifically to communicate measurements, or values and relationships.
In this next exercise we learn to communicate the position of a train as time passes and develop the notation to express where the train is at different times.

statement.p: Consider the graph below.
The dot on the graph represents the position of a train at a particular time. The crosshairs represent the time.
Adjust the time by sliding crosshairs left and right. Notice that the train's distance, in miles, from downtown depends on the time, in hours, after 8 a.m.
Without knowing anything about function notation, you can still use a language you already know, English, to describe information about the train.

For instance:
The train can only be in one place at any particular time.
As time passes the train gets farther from downtown.
The speed of the train changes during its trip.

There are also some aspects of the graph itself that you can easily describe in English:
The graph rises as we read it from left to right.
Sometimes the graph is curved upwards.
Sometimes the graph curves downwards.
Some parts of the graph are steeper than others.
In this lesson we learn to describe situations in math language using function notation. Later the notation itself will allow us to use math in making calculations.

subsection.p: In English you can communicate information about time and position in a simple sentence like

blockquote.p: 2 hours after 8 a.m. the train is 30 miles from downtown.

subsection.p: Here is what that same sentence looks like in Spanish.

blockquote.p: 2 horas despues de las 8 de la ma√±ana el tren esta 30 millas lejos del centro.

subsection.p: Here is what that same sentence could look like in math.

Let's piece apart the English sentence so you can see the structure as it compares to math. In English we tell the reader what we are talking about. This is the subject, The position of the train 2 hours after 8 a.m. and in math we can simply say, f(2).

Now the reader is wondering, so what about this train's position? Is it more than something, less than something, is growing, shrinking, what? In our example we just want to say what the distance is. In math is means equals but we use the symbol, =.
Finally we want to tell the reader the punch line. We want to tell them that the distance is 30 miles from downtown at the specified time. Hence, f(2) = 30 is the entire senctence.

subsection.title: The Grammar of Function Notation
subsection.p: The math sentence above is actually an equation and it uses function notationfunctionnotationnotationfor functions to express the information about the train. Of course, the equation is meaningless unless the reader knows how the variables and the function is defined. If you know Spanish or math you can interpret the meaning of something you read in those languages into English. Likewise, if you know math language you can interpret function notation its meaning into English too. There will be much interpretation in this class.

In math we use variables and symbols to replace entire words or even entire sentences. Instead of Train's distance in miles from downtown we can use the variable D. Instead of the number of hours after 8 a.m., we can use the variable t.

We call the letters D and t variables because they represent values that can change. Typically we use variables that have something to do with the context of the problem, but sometimes we generalize an expression or equation with x's and y's when we have nothing specific in mind.
If the variables represent actual things or events we must define the varialbles to include the units we used to measure the event.

blockquote.p: If D is distance you must define the units in which the distance is measured: miles, inches, centimeters, light yearswhat?
If t is time, will it be measured with units of seconds, hoursyears?

subsection.p: Since the position of the train depends on the amount of time that has passed, we say the distance depends on time. In fact, the distance of the train from downtown is a function of time.

Function notation allows us to communicate that distance is a function of time by simply writing D = f(t) [say, D equals f of t]. Don't confuse the notation with multiplication! f(t) does not mean f times t.

subsection.p: The format of function notation works on the basic principle of input and output.

Choose some input, like a time, and the function gives an output like a distance. The notation tells the reader what the input is by showing it in the parentheses.f(\text{input}) = \mathit{output} In the train problem, the function notation f(0) is telling us the input is 0. The value 0 in the parentheses means, 0 hours after 8 a.m. In other words it's 8 a.m.

On the other hand, f(0) is an output. It represents the train's distance from downtown, 0 hours after 8 a.m. Together, the input and output create an ordered pairordered pair (0, f(0)). On a graph the ordered pair is a pointpoint.

subsection.title: Evaluate
subsection.p: It's one thing to talk about The train's distance from downtown 2 hours after 8 a.m. and a completely different thing to say what that distance actually is.

In our train story f(2) represents the train's distance 2 hours after 8 a.m. To find the value (number) for the distance we must evaluate the funtion. Earlier we used a graph, but can use a table or a formula if there is one avaible. The important thing is we need an input of time to determine the output which is the actual distance of the train from downtown.
To evaluateevaluate a function means to find the value of the output given an input value. Therefore, evaluate f(2) in our example means Find the train's distance from downtown 2 hours after 8 a.m.
Again, typically we use graphs, tables or formulas to evaluate funtions.

statement.p: Remember in a vertical table the inputs are found in the left column (independent variable) while outputs are found in the right column (dependent variable)
Use the table to evaluate f(2.5)

subsection.p: In general when the inputs and outputs are nothing in particular, we use x as input and y as output so that y = f(x). We use x as symbol to hold a spot for the actual input value while y is a spot holder for whatever the output value will be. The x basically says, When you get the input, put it here in all the places where the x is.
Consider the function f(x) = 50x + 10. The function has no context (no story) so we won't bother using units for either x or y.
If x = 1 then we can evaluate f(1) by replacing the x in the formula with a 1. Literally, f(1) means, the formula with a 1 in it.

subsection.p: The most important part is that for each input the function yields only one result, and each individual input always gives the same single result. This sound terribly confusing, but it makes more sense if we just think about the train.

For instance, for the train fuction D = f(t) at any given time like t = 2 the train can only be in one place. That's the only result. It's not possible for the train to be in two or more places (results) at the same time. Also, every time you put 2 into the function, the train is always in the same place.

Here is the tricky part. It is possible that the train is 30 miles away from downtown at 10 a.m., on the way out of town. But then the train is 30 miles away from downtown later in the day (different time) on the way back towards downtown. Still the train is only at one place at any one time.

subsection.title: The Secret to Evaluating Anything (The Blank Method)
subsection.p: Function notation is a way to tell the reader information about the input and how to use it to generate an output. Again, the way it works is f(\text{input})=\text{output}. Whatever is in the parenthesis is the input.
The input can be a simple number like 2 or -4 or the input can be a complicated expression like x^2 - x.
Your success in this course is almost entirely dependent on your understanding of this simple concept: The blank method.
When you see a formula like f(x) = x^2 - x. It means this:f(\text{blank}) = (\text{blank}) - (\text{blank})
At least that's the way formulas really work.
Using this function as an example, f(5) means The formula with a 5in it. Literally it means place number 5 in all the blanks. As inf(5) = (5)^2 - (5) = 20
The beauty of this is it does not matter what you put into the formula (as long as the formula can handle it which we will get into later), the formula does the same thing every time.

You can put 5 into the formula or you can put something complicated into the formula like \frac{x^2}{x^2 + 1} which would look like thisf\mathopen{}\left(\frac{x^2}{x^2 + 1}\right)\mathclose{} = \mathopen{}\left(\frac{x^2}{x^2 + 1}\right)^2\mathclose{} - \mathopen{}\left(\frac{x^2}{x^2 + 1}\right)\mathclose{}
Simplifying this equation is another matter.

subsection.title: Solve
subsection.p: What if the output, the result, is already known and we want to know all the inputs that give us this result? This is called solvesolve.
Solve means to work backwards from a known or given output value and determine all the inputs, if any, that give us the desired output.

Suppose we want the output of a function to be y =0. Therefore, we must find all the input values of x that gives us that result. There may not be any, but there could be one, several or even infinite possible inputs that gives y = 0 as the output.
In English we could ask the question for the example in the previous exercise,

blockquote.p: What input makes the output equal to 0?

subsection.p: There would be three answers:x = - 4 , -1\text{ or }2
All of these values of x give us the same result of y = 0.
In math we could ask the same question, but it comes out as a statement.
Solve means, Find the input that gives you this result. In our case the result we want is an output value of 0. There are still three answers to the question and each answer is called a solution.
The statement:
has three solutions: x = -4, -1 \text{ and }2
On a graph, the output is the height of the graph. Solve f(x) = 0 on a graph means, Find all the places where the graph is zero units high.

The math sentence Solve the equation f(x) = 4.57 means, find all the x-values where the graph of the function reaches 4.57 units high. this equation may have one, several, or infinite or even no solutions.
